Bottle, saved from the release in May for the big 1,000 (!) Rate Beer check-in. Believe the hype. This,to me, is the pinnacle of what an obsessively crafted beer can taste like. Every element is executed brilliantly -- theres a light touch of bready malt flavor, faint hop bitterness, and a cacophony of wine, cider, fruit, and funk flavors from the yeast and barrel aging -- but everything comes together in a beautiful balance. The mouthfeel stands out, with a light and dry opening that lasts surprisingly long, allowing the flavors to all linger. Very reminiscent of wine, with lots of tannin and bright fruit aromas. I cant tell if Im crying from how good this tastes or how sad I am that Ill probably never drink it again.

b4. Merci à Marc-André pour le partage de cette magnifique rareté! Dun point de vue esthétique, le liquide ressemble beaucoup à Arthur, exception faite que cette déclinaison me paraît plus huileuse, résultat sans doute attribuable au vieillissement en barrique de vin blanc. Arômes bien ficelées de vin blanc et de houblons citronnés qui nous ramène à Arthur. Belle rondeur en bouche, le liquide est toutefois bien moins beurré qu anticipé. Le trio funk-houblons-vin blanc est maîtrisé à la perfection et se présente à moi en toute légèreté. Vu le prix et la rareté de ce produit très attendu par le monde entier, je mattendais à un niveau de complexité supérieur. Lensemble est remarquablement équilibré et demeure somme toute straight-forward. Très ou trop facile à boire, cette bière se doit à mon avis dêtre dégustée sur la terrasse à lapéro par une belle fin daprès-midi dété - tel que nous lavons fait.

April 2014 Magnum shared by Adam C on 7/25/15.Another fantastic pour, obviously having had a good deal of time to really build up plenty of carbonation in the bottle. Large white head tops a soft golden, lightly hazy body.I believe as soon as we started drinking this, immediately following Arthur (could be Ann vs Anna, but its the same argument), someone said right away, "Wow, not even close between this and Arthur." (implying this, being barrel-aged, was way better). I VERY quickly disagreed and while I dont know if its better or worse, I dont like that barrel aging is just automatically associated with higher quality, more finely crafted beers. Sure, the beer takes longer to produce but I dont think that says anything about quality. Im not always in the mood for a more dull, tannic, lactic, generally drier, lighter beer. Especially the case here, where I much preferred the aroma on Arthur, being completely different and vastly brighter. Still just as complex despite the lack of the wine and wood element. I think people often vastly overestimate the effect barrel-aging has on a beer.ANYWAYS....this was much more reserved in the nose than CD14; not a noseful of wine at all and the sauv blanc is very nicely integrated, allowing citrus, vanilla and light cereal grain notes. Dulled by the tannin, as expected, and I much prefer the regular versions aroma.Strong acids in the mouth show grape and lactic influences, with honey-like maltiness, bread dough and moderate fruitiness (stone fruits, light citrus). Lip smacking acidity on the end is very well balanced thanks to the attenuation level, which is near-perfect here, allowing enough malt texture and sugar to balance. Lemons and soft, light floral notes linger. Tight carbonation as always from HF.

750ml bottle. Batch 2, aged at least 5-6 months...maybe a bit more. The pour yields a medium golden body that starts out mostly clear, but becomes increasingly cloudy with each careful pour. A thick head of off-white froth holds strong, fading very slowly. Dense swaths of fluffy lace coat nearly the entire glass. On the nose, the wine barrel influence is immediate and pervasive. Dry, vinous oak comes across peppery and spicy. Following is ample white grape must, elderflower, and secondary hints of tart berry fruit. After clearing the initial tart, oaky blanket, a base of wheat and dry cereal grain emerges, setting the stage for hints of orange peel and distant coriander. It smells quite dusty, showing signature Hill Farmstead house funk. Hops are floral as can be, suggesting of citrus blossoms and maybe a touch of lemongrass. With a fantastic aroma to live up to, the flavor does not disappoint. Again supremely oaky, showing peppery, mineralic tendencies backed by sharp white and link fruit, the wine takes center stage. Dried, dusty wheat and crushed dry flowers move in, followed by some citrus acidity and tart, funky farmhouse yeast. So many layers, I could go on for days. The palate is effervescent, lending a champagne-like tingle to the dry body. The acidity is bracing up front, giving way to a surprisingly lengthy hop finish. The elderflower character reminds me of somethign from Fantôme or Cazeau, only more refined and complex than both. What can I say? Another masterpiece from Shaun Hill. This is almost becoming routine.

The beer pours from the bottle with a pale, touch of haze to it, gold color and it is topped by a pale head of froth. Herbal hop notes are noticeable up front in the aroma, with a hint of citrus, some peppery yeast character, a mustiness, and even a hint of plastic like phenolics being noticeable. A cracker like malt character provides a nice, pale grain note to the nose that helps to round things out.

The beer is dry, almost woody, and has a hint of tartness to it as it first hits the palate. A bitter, biting hop character is noticeable from the front of each sip thorugh to the lingering finish; some green hop notes especially linger on the tongue. An earthy, yeast derived spice character in the finish melds with the hop character (specifically the hay, and coriander like notes), and woody, pepper-like notes. This is very light bodied, as a Saison should be, it is really refreshing, but has lots of firmness to the flavor. This is quite nice, really enjoyable, and a I really would like a bottle of this to contemplate on my own. This has a huge flavor, is sharp, gripping, spicy, with enough pale malt character to tie things together, and it is just oh-so quaffable.

Gold pour with a small white head. Nose is good balanced collage of fruit, sweaty wild yeast, light acidic wine barrel, stone fruit. Mouth is dry, fairly acidic, salty Brett. Funky and tart, lots of very dry mineral flavors. Pretty good, nowhere near the level of some of their other barrel aged gold saisons aka Ann and civil disobedience 5.

Bottle shared at the November 2012 Santa Cruz tasting. Pours a light clear gold with a filmy white head. Funky fruity aroma, stone fruit, grape, strawberry. Champagne notes with grape and oak, bretty dry finish, mildly tart.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2014 Le liquide ne mattend pas pour sortir, il dicte les règles dès le départ mais sans faire de dégât. Larôme de vin blanc sauvage envahi la pièce rapidement. En bouche cest aussi complexe que facile à boire avec sa corpulence vineuse, son zeste dagrume et le chatouillement des houblons herbacés qui nous propulse vers une finale sèche et surette totalement approprié. Dans lensemble, un niveau de buvabilité et de complexité rarement atteint dans le même liquide.

Bottle at home poured into my HF wine glass. Appearance is golden orange with a frothy white, long-lasting head and great lacing. Funk, light urine, honey, band-aid, rubber, light spice, straw, grass, biscuit, and citrus in the aroma. Nice! Taste is tart lemon peel, zest, tangy fruit peel, biscuit, bread, grass, white pepper, and clove with am lightly spicy/tart finish. Creamy mouthfeel with high carbonation. Funky, fruity, refreshing, and satisfying. Another great brew from Shaun. You really cant go wrong with any beer from Hill Farmstead. Awesome!

Bottle at November tasting.  Light to golden straw colored with a medium white head. Mild nose, with a touch of fruit and funk.  Taste was very crisp, a bit of sweet fruit, nice and dry, wtih a sharp, crisp aftertaste.

Bottle shared by Thorpe429. Thanks Mike.

Served along side Hill Farmstead Arthur, Flora, Civil Disobedience, and McKenzie Irma Extra.

The beer appears hazy and yellow hued with a half inch of white head and some decent lacing. The aroma is fabulous. Red wine, wild yeast, floral notes, citrus, funk. Yeah, Im digging this. The flavor is very good, though not quite as remarkable as the aroma. Nice feel on the palate. Complex and delicious. This was my favorite of the five saisons I sampled that night. I would enjoy having this again. Recommended.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-02-2011

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 pour is transparent pale yellow with a tight white head.  Nose is balanced Saison with light sweetness in back and some barrel overtones up front. Hints of dustiness towards the back with lemon behind.  Taste is a bit more acidic, barrel is a touch stronger, lemony in back with some peppery mineral notes mid palate. Finish is crisp, high carbonation and fairly dry.

Bottle. Thanks Steve for sending my way! Pours a light golden color with a fluffy white head. Aroma is a nice belnd of saison funkiness, green apple, and wine notes. Lots of florals. Med mouthfeel. Some tarness mixed with the floral and wine flavors. Overall, a nice drinking beer.
Bottle shared by kbutler1!  Hazy yellow pour, plenty of head/lacing and an aroma of light lemon.  Flavor was also slightly dry lemon, light funk, slightly creamy body and very enjoyable.

Bottle from hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours clear light amber with a thin white head. Nose is white pepper, white wine, light toasty oak, and pale malt. Taste is tropical fruit, dusty yeast, light pepper, dry malt, and oak. Smooth carbonation and a thin body--really pleasant in the mouth.
bottle, thanks to thirdeye11, pulpy yellow with creamy white foam, pineapple creamy sour aromas, flavor is pineapple uside down cake, aspirin and wildflowers, good finish

Bottle given to me by lushawn. Batch 2. Wow, thanks Shawn. Gave me an Arthur and now this. Looks like Im going to fall in line with the last several raters with my rating. Gushed initially, but possibly due to my handling. Pours a hazy, pale gold with a big, frothy white head that laces the glass. Aroma of floral notes, bretty funk, white wine, oak, straw, gass, and herbs. The flavor adds lemon to the mix, with less earthy notes. Bread, straw, light funk, white wine grapes. Light-medium bodied, with a tart, dry, bready mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Could drink this all day. Awesome.

Had on tap at Harvest, however forgot to write a review for this remarkable beer until now. From cellphone text to myself. Poured a hazed, woody gold waxed amber with a snowy white head. Smells of poppy seeds right away, followed by lemon tarts, wheat bread, brief citrus tang, yeast, white wine dregs, oak, peach syrup, and some sour grass. Tastes predominately of the regular Arthur, only with a bit of oak to it and certainly has more of a tart sting.

On tap at the HF Harvest Fest. Hazy gold pour with white head. Aroma is grainy, bread, white wine and brett. Taste is slightly oaky, chardonnay like white wine notes, some brett is present as well. Palate is tart and dry albeit a relatively thick body, carbonation is medium. Classic HF know-how.

The aroma is a really nice bouquet of citrus, lemon zest, floral hops, hay, fresh air, white wine and barnyard funk (is there Brett in this? I see no mention on the bottle description) and I dont know why but Im thinking of glaciers. It just smells FRESH and clean. On to the appearance. This is a beautiful hazy golden color with the whitest and most fluffiest head there is, which also sticks around and coats the surface like a snowy northeastern lake in the winter time. Lots of visible bubbles. Lacing is thick and sticky. This is a really good looking beer! Taste is of oak, white wine, lemon zest, a little barnyard tang and some slight hop earthy bitterness to balance it out. This is definitely a highly carbonated beer, and so it should be. Its crisp, clean, and goes down very easily despite its high level of bloatiness. Overall, this beer is awesome and has solidified to me the popularity of Hill Farmstead. Im glad I got to try this and wish I could source this locally. Upright from Portland makes some very similar beers in their Sole Comp series. Art tastes very reminiscent of an Upright saison so if youre in the PNW and need your HF fix Upright is a very equal alternative. Good stuff, cant wait to try more HF!

Bottle. Big thanks to KyotoLefty. Fields of flowers, spices, barrels of pickles, and a lake of lemon. Hazy gold color, HUGE head, great lacing. Initial is complete and sour as can be; mid palate develops the sourness and gathers fruity fullness; final goes smooth in increments. Medium body, with a lot of carb tingling. A real workout for the tongue. Great!

Lemon, wine barrel, mineral, light belgian yeast, and hay on the nose. Pours hazy light golden, nice white head and great lace. Nice looking beer. Flavors of lemon, pepper, belgian yeast esters, wine barrel, dust, mineral notes, hay. Well done use of barrel, subtle, dry, nice.

(750ml bottle) cloudy medium gold, white lasting bubbles. Nose of wine barrel, lasting white head, white pepper, juicy stone fruit, so complex and amazing. Taste of stone fruit, earth (the hill farmstead terroir), wine barrel, dry, complex, spices, Belgian yeast thats spicy in just the right way. Dry body, so easy drinking and ridiculously complex.
On draft @ Festival of Farmhouse Ales.  Wonderful lemon brett character, super bright & refreshing in both flavor & carbonation.  Great stuff!
tap at farmhouse. pours orange with white head. aroma of sour apples and spice. taste is very crisp funky and tart little oaky wine also

Draught at the Festival of Farmhouse Ales. Beautiful orange-gold with a thick, fine head. Funky brett nose, citrus, a little yogurt, barnyard, just lovely. A really nice sour tanginess, light, good sweetness, good balance, grapefruit and lemon, a little spice. Really light, full, fabulous.

Sharply tart, with bright pangs of sweet-sour citrus throughout; very herbal, and dry; lots of great zesty/dusty character owing to a thoroughly perfect blending of yeasts, barrel, and hops.  Palate is mouth puckering; not quite enough body or rounding; still, really lovely.

On tap at the 2012 Hill Farmstead Festival of Farmhouse Ales. What a way to start to start a festival! Love the big, fluffy booming cotton and grapefruit Brett aroma. Such a strong and pleasant sensation. The ultradry powdery texture keeps it fresh and lively and carries the flavors through well. Refreshing, complex and elegant. Champagne-like.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2013 bottle. pours hazed lemon wh head, nose yeasty floral, fl yeasty bomb,
spicy floral. Just okay. 3.4.

9/2012 draft pour at Hill Harvest fest, labeled Blue Label, which I guess is what all future Art releases will be. I found this much better than the previous bottle Art rate. pours blond with huge head, funky and bretty foral notes with pepper and citrus. flavors is pretty, horsey, bright oranges, sweet bread. peppery finish. great stuff.

Bottle pours a hazy golden/yellow with a huge white head. Aroma of lemon zest, grass, wine, oak, funk, and yeast spice. Taste is light and bitter tart, lemon grass, barn yard funk, pineapple, straw, wine grapes, dry with a light yeast spice. Everything is balanced perfectly, light, dry, and refreshing. Yum!

Bottles.  Hazy golden color with loads of lacing.  Fucking right!  Loads of Brett in the aroma.  Yeasty, fruity character.  Smells lovely.  God I wish I hadnt drank so much lately.  Nice and dry.  Pineapple, spice, and pretty acidic.  Its good, but maybe Im missing what makes this unbelievable.
bottle.    notes of white wine grapes,   moderate lemonzest yogurt sourness.   dusty, light leather fog funk.    well balanced.     dry.   complex.  refreshing.  like.

750 ml shared at Toochs tasting. Thanks, buddy. Batch 2. Pours a richly deep hazed golden hue, a bit dulled, deep and hazy with big cakey whitish head that laces well. Thick rich film. Laces well. Big hazy hue. Aromas are richly citrusy and fruity, a touch of spice, gentle yeast, bready malts, touches of straw. Initial is medium bodied, offering gentle spice and yeast, gentle fruit, apple and melon, mixes with touches of pear, gentle yeast and spice. Middle offers some sweetness, bready and doughy malt with fruity ester elements, touches of crab apple, lemon. Touches of citrus, dry florals, gentle oak with a kiss of winey oak. Backend and finish offers a touch of tartness, green apple, with gentle yeast, spice, and bready malts. Some gentle elements. Solid beer, but not my favorite out of the series.

Picked this up at the bottle release a few months back. Stored at 60 Degrees then placed it in the fridge an hour before serving. Enjoyed in a Hill Farmstead glass with friends. 

A - Bright golden orange with lots of haze. 4-finger solid white head with tight bubbles

S - Its really nice on the nose. Very floral and grassy. Mild level of lemon zest and oakiness.

T - Taste is up front very citrusy and a mild level of peppery spice. Hints of lemons and cloves. Finish is tart and somewhat funky. 

M - 60% carbonation on the mouth swish. Light body. Tart finish.

O - Art is easily twice as good as Arthur but I gave Arthur a big rating I certainly cant double the rating so Im just gonna give it the best I can.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 750 ml bottle @ Mikkeller Bar. Pours hazy golden with a big frothy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving some trace and lacing on the glass. Smell is tiny sweet, slightly sour, fruity and funky with crackers, dry wood, hay, plums, green grapes, dry soil, lemon juice, barnyard, lemon zest and hints of cereal, dried dandelions, white pepper and lemon balm. Taste is tiny sweet, slightly bitter and tiny sour with dry soil, hay, dry wood, grape zest, white pepper, lemon zest, cloves, grapefruit zest, leather, red wine, barnyard, dry tobacco, straw and plums. Mouthfeel is round, dry, slightly tart and medium bodied. Finish is bitter and tiny sour with crackers, hay, dry soil, grape zest, plums, lemon zest and dry wood. Another bleeping good beer from Hill Farmstead <3.

Got the unique opportunity to try batch 1 and batch 2 side by side.  Batch one is a lightly hazy gold with a very frothy, creamy, white head.  Nose is grassy, herbal, floral, white pepper, dandelion greens.  Flavor is sweet, tart, herbal, grassy, white pepper.  Medium bodied, lightly astringent finish.  Batch 2 looks the same.  Softer head.  Nose is less herbal, a little sweeter.  Heavier carb, more sugar, more tropical fruit.  Some white grape.  I liked batch 2 a bit more.

Pour at Scotts saison tasting, pour out of 750 mL bottle batch 2.  Hazy orange with white head pour, aroma brought notes of wine, grape, biscuit, some lemon/lactic, hints of funky basement, touch of spicy peppers as well.  Taste is a mix of oak, vanilla, some nice white wine and grape, hints of lemon, biscuit, lactic acid notes with a funky grass note, touch of honey.  Dry finish, slightly sweet.

Bottle from dtmets84.  The pour is a golden color with a thick lasting white head.  Very nice.  The aroma shows off a lot of the wine character for sure.  A woody note joins in, along with damp funk, herbal notes, citrus fruit consisting of peaches and mango.  This is tart and clean going down; definitely a good palate cleanser and rather dry.  A little lighter in the body than expected.  Quite thirst quenching and refreshing.  The flavors are tart citrus fruit, some light grass, white grape, and oak.  Call me crazy, but I like the base (Arthur) a little better.  And I like Anna better than that one.  Still, this is a very fine brew.
just a touch of wood/barrel character. A nice saison, some wine character with touch of citrus.

Flaske: Gul let diset øl der bliver mere og mere uklar. Duften er brett, men det er meget tydeligt at den har ligget på rødvinsfade. Meget astringent i smagen fra rødvinsfadene, men den vinder på en. Andet glas er rigtig god. Fin fin øl.

750 thanks to Matt. Really nice carbonated pour. Golden ale in color. Aroma of just a bit of funk and brett. Taste is lemon and dry white wine. Some oak in the taste, but not very dominant. Just a lovely saison as usual from Hill Farmstead.

750 mL bottle, batch 2. Pours a clear amber color with a thin creamy head. Decent head retention. Aroma of bready malts, honey, spicy hops and a wine note. The taste is tart tannic notes, intense citrus and tropical notes. Medium bodied.

750mL bottle, courtesy of joet. Thanks, Joe! Pours a bright, hugely effervescent deep golden color; huge, textured white head with great retention an dlacing. Some light grapefruity / lemony tartness in the aroma, along with a subtle peppery note and light oakiness; soft, plush, precise, with a touch of red fruitiness. Medium body; lively, effervescent carbonation; lightly acidic lemons, a touch of tartness, and a creamy vanilla and oaky core, with a slight funky / musty quality. Absolutely delicious, and the most compelling Hill Farmstead beer Ive had so far. Toasty, nicely dry finish with a touch of lingering oak and soft bitterness.

Lively effervescence, pillowy white head, soft rose water, mildly tannic, earthy aromas, moist hay, citric elements, well done dryness, the yeast at the bottom adds a touch of sourness as well as color and texture to the final pour. Among my favorites from Hill Farmstead. This is gorgeous.

750 ml bottle poured a hazy gold with a small lasting creamy white head. Aroma of straw, lemon, yeast, light spice and light funk. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry tart finish. Flavors of straw, lemon, yeast and light barnyard funk with a crisp dry tarty lingering funky citrus finish.

Batch 1 bottle: Pours a clear bright golden with a stringy-lacing white head.  Has a lightly earthy funky nose with a touch of yeasty esters and a hint of cork.  Starts with light effervescence and oxidation with some soft malty sweetness and vinous oak notes before a drier, earthy brett finish.  Pretty complex, but this bottle seems slightly corked and oxidized.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2012 Bottle @ Scotts Summer Saison tasting. Thanks so much Scott! Thanks also to Armin for trading for this gem! Cloudy yellow appearance with a white head. Fairly tart, musty, white wine, pear, citrusy aroma. Nice vinous, apple, somewhat tart, lemony acidic, refreshing flavor. Kick ass. (4.2)Bottle with Jetson in Vail for Christmas. Beautiful, glowing orange appearance with a big, lasting fluffy white head. Potent dry, white wine, spicy peppery, somewhat funky, big barnyard, lemon/tangerine fruity aroma. A bit tart, lemony, musty, white grape, apple, dry, chewy straw flavor. Really a nice brew. (4.2)
Bottle at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Yellow hazy beer with a white lacy big head. Citrus, fruity, hoppy, oak, spicy aroma. Earth, grapes, citrus, perfume, fruity, oak and spicy flavour.

Bottle from the 1st anniversary aged for a year in my cellar perfectly. Pours yellow clear in color with a big beautiful white head. The aroma is fresh spring grassy meadow notes, lightly not quite floral sweet soft and pleasant. The flavor brings spring farmhouse ale flavors and then it ends a bit dry on the palate with some grassy notes.

750 mL bottle, poured into a tulip.

Pours a filtered, hazed golden straw color with a dense, frothy white head that initially fills the glass. Abundant lacing coats the glass and the head has nice retention supported by a consistent stream of bubbles.

Aroma is very dry, vinous and yeasty. Some residual sweetness with oak/vanilla, ripe grapes, and banana but earth and red wine dominate. Not much presence of spice or funk. 

Smooth, medium-thick body. Soft, fine carbonation with a dry, oaky finish. Docking the mouthfeel a little for the finish which is very tannic and oaky. 

Similar experience as Sean preceding me. Not as much wine as the aroma, more vanilla and woodsy oak. More brett funk comes through suppressing the fruity and yeasty sweetness of the aroma.

Another well made, good but not great saison from HF. I enjoy this more than the base Art I had a few months ago, but the wine barrel (particularly oak flavors) are a little too strong. Reminiscent of McKenzies Saison Vautour and honestly a little more consistent in composition. However Vautour is still the standard I look for in this style of wine barrel/wild saisons.

(Bottle) Pours cloudy yellow to pale golden with an off-white head. The aroma holds mouldy basement, ginger, spicy wood, grapes, dust, dirt, perfume, roses, crackers, dough, lemon, lime, grapefruit, a touch of phenols and tart fruits. The flavour is light sweet to dry, light  bitter and light to medium acidic with notes of mould, light funk, citrus, wood, spices, wine/grapes, crackers and dust.the mouthfeel is soft, tart and tannin-driven with a light carbonation. Dry, woodsy, limey, bready and light dirty finish. Light to medium bodied.

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar. Hazy yellow beer with a white lasting head. Spicy hoppy aroma, citrus, oak, perfume, horse blanket, citrus, fruits, grapefruit. Sourish perfume flavor, hoppy, grassy, grapefruit, wheat notes, spices, fruity notes, oak and some apples. Bitter perfume flavor with grassy and fruity notes.

A - pours nice hazy golden straw yellow with very high fluffy white that lasts forever. Strong lacing immediately. S - really nice saison aromas. Hay, barnyard funk, grasses up front. Nice fruity notes apple and pineapple, nice oak and Chardonnay notes. Hints of spicy saison. 10 M - interesting play in the mouth. Nice strong flavors on the nose that disappear quickly, weak palate, to a lingering dry almost flavorless bitterness. T - nice grassy spicy saison up front, with notes of barnyard funk,  yeast up front. Citrus notes of grapefruit, dry  non sweet apple, oak and Chardonnay on the palate. Lingering bitter grassy and dry apple end. O - better as it warms. Fantastic aromas to a less than spectacular tastes. Would be spectacular if it has strong fruit notes or more of the chardonnay notes. Still, very good.  3.8

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2014 Sample from bottle. Poured a hazy orange shade. Thin white head. Aromas are on the funky side: apple, barnyard funk, spicy saison yeast. Taste is bready, minty, maybe some dried apricot, oaky. Very complex beer that was hard to pin down. Everything worked well together from what I remember. 
Bottle new batch, pours hazy golden with white head and lots of lace. Notes are kiwi, lemons, and dark grape skins. Medium bodied with lactic lemonade funk.

Thanks to Biggsbowler for sharing.  Straw yellow pour with a huge white head.  Muted lemon nose.  Medium in body and mild in sourness and acidity.  Yeast and lemon notes with just a hint of oak.  Its definitely a saison!
On draft.  Yellow color with a light white head.  Earthy classic saison taste with a touch of wood.  Smoother version of arthur.

Bottle thanks to WeisGuy. 01/15/2012.  Pours hazy golden straw color, medium rocky head, sticky lacing, active bubbles.  Aroma has brett, oak, strong chardonnay notes, incredibly fruity with white grapes, apple, and pears, mild tart character.  Taste carries vibrant vinous notes, green grapes, lemon skin, slightly sweet, transition to bready malts, soft herbal bitterness, long dry aftertaste.  Medium in the mouth with nice carbonation, remains crisp and dry.  Really great saison from Hill Farmstead, beautiful barrel treatment.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2015 750mL bottle, sent from gn0sis (thanks Eric), pours a cloudy dark-ish orange with a small white head. Aroma of yeast, some sour funk, dry fruits (pears, apples), and barnyard. Flavour of spices, barnyard funk, lots of oak, some dry zesty fruits and a spicy, doughy finish. Great complexity with a great funky, spicy finish. The barrels certainly impart an oaky quality to this, amping up the complexity even more. Phenomenal stuff.

bottle at rbwg 3/5/11.

hazy orange-yellow with a lasting medium sized white head.

aromas of bretty cement/stone/slate, cobwebs, orange, grainy husks, hay, grass and peppery spice.

the flavor has additional notes of vinous wood, flowers and wet wood.

it is dry and medium bodied. the mouth feel has an odd artificial sugar feel to it.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée avec MartinT et Fred82. Merci. Arôme: Odeur de brett et dagrumes. Apparence: La couleur est blonde opaque. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de brett et dagrumes avec une pointe de poivre. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence dagrumes en arrière goût. (Rating #3938)

Thanks to Adrian for popping open another beer he went way out into the woods to score.  Green-gold pour.  An unbelievably rocky head, the rockiest head ever -  it looks like a mountain top - is this a Hill Farmstead signature move?  Lightly sour-sweet aroma with some yeast.  It tastes of white wine (it was aged in wine barrels) and fresh bread.  Nice and peppery on the palate.  Very fine - I am surprised I liked a wine barrel aged brew this much.

Pour from a 750 ml. bottle into the glass gave a light golden color with a voluminous white head. Aromas present were of hay, yeast, grass, and a bit of peppery spice. Light in body with appropriate and pleasant carbonation. Flavors coming up were lemony citrus, white grape, wine , oak, and a bit of earthy funk. A bit of hop balance but not too much. The finish up being rather dry. Really liked this Saison.

1st October 2011Bottle shared at the Kernel Brewery. Thanks to tendermorsel for sharing - Cheers Mike! Hazy gold beer, good cream coloured head. Very dry palate, semi soft. Dusty wet wood - like licking a broom handle that has been in the cellar for months. A little hop bitterness. Dry finish. Pretty grim and I drain poured half my glass.

Phone rate. 750mL, no date from the brewery back in May. Hazy gold with a 1 1/2 finger creamy off-white head, good retention. Fantome saison yeasty nose, some white pepper, as well as musty dank basement.  Some oak as well. Flavor yeasty and musty dominant, cobwebby. Dry finish, bitterness 3and earthy. Light to medium body, mod creamy carbonation. Tasty.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 750ml Bottle (at 6.5%ABV per the bottle):  Complex aroma of grain, fruit, pale malt, melon, light Brett, slight oak, slight spicy yeast, apple, and slight leather, slight barnyard.  Poured yellow/gold/orange in color with a medium-sized, loose, creamy, white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Flavor is slightly sweet and heavily Bretty.  Tastes of Brett, oak, slight fruit, leather, yeast, and more Brett.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Bitter, Brett, yeast finish is dry.
2010 version from the harvest festival.  This funky saison was remarkably clean and fresh on the finish.  Notes of lemon, spices, funk, orange zest, and an herbal finish.  Very tasty stuff

Bottle at Kernel Brewery tasting. It pours golden orange, with a thin foamy white head. The nose is tart orange, tangerine, wet wood, leaves and medicinal notes. The taste is dusty, orange pith, tangerine, medicinal, white bread, cork and light spice, with a citric finish. Medium body and fine carbonation.
UPDATED: MAY 13, 2012 Very clean, flawless profile, light Brett on nose, saison finish. Beatifiul beer

My second HF beer.  The first beer Rarl was terrific.  This one was rather ordinary.  Funky saison yeast.  Generous retained head on hazy golden coloured body.  Above average mouthfeel.  Funky, yeasty taste, pepper.  Dry bitter finish.  Decent drinkability but it took many sips. Thanks Steve S.

Bottle shared at The Kernel with Evin and Nate, thanks to Shaun. I was focused on enjoying this beer with the Kernel lads so didnt focus on notes until the dust had settled, as it were. Some recollections, which dont necessarily do the beer justice: Lovely appearance. Clean. Maximum complexity. Grass, fresh funk. Watching Nate drink this was a treat. He would alternate from complete silence to basically jibberish as he enumerated the myriad ways in which this beer was perfect. I mostly stayed silent, enjoying one of the best beers I have ever tasted.

The pour reveals a clear golden color with a thick, rocky white head. Very appealing aroma of hops, fruits, hay and yeast with a mild woody presence coming from the barrel. The flavor is wonderfull, theres hops, fruits, yeast, restrained tartness and wood, along some spicyness that could be coming from the yeast. Theres some bitterness in the end. The body is medium with a creamy texture and medium carbonation. Ive come to expect solid beers from Hill Farmstead, but this is definitely over any expectations I could have had, its amazing.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle. Appears a lightly hazy golden color with a large billowing head. Smell is intense funk and wine grape, light oak. Lots of fruity esters. Taste is rich with funky esters in the bready biscuity malt. Lots of clean funky saison esters.  A touch tannic. light white grape vinous with a tannic red touch. mouthfeel is medium body with a lot of carbonation. Overall a very enjoyable saison.

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Poured pale, golden/straw color with a white head.  This had a serious mineral, earthy quality that tasted similar to drinking pennies.  All this mixed with a tartness from the yeast characters.

Bottle. Glass is half white foam and cloudy dark yellow. Strong peppery funky nose. Light body with strong flavour. Lots of spice and a hint of lemon. Some subtle woody notes that I would not normally pick out as barrel aging not having had Arthur.
Draft. Pours a golden yellow with lots of head. slightly funky/sour smell. Taste isnt as sour as the nose would lead you to believe. Finishes sweet and clean. very thirst quenching.

Bouteille de 750 ml. Arômes de brettanomyces, de vin blanc et de chêne. Très belle robe blonde, légèrement voilée, belle mousse qui tient bien et effervescence active. Très complexe et équilibrée en bouche, la présence du fût de vin est plus importante que dans la Flora mais moins que dans la Phenomenology of Spirit. Le fût contribue des notes fruitées, vineuses et boisées. La base de céréales est très croustillante et la levure de saison montre un beau côté de paille fraîche. Finale très sèche, moyennement tannique et délicatement acidulé. Une autre très belle saison de Hill Farmstead.

Bottle shared by fred82 , thank you!
Murky golden pour, with a very large offwhite head. Nice funky aroma, some nice citrus, and quite a bit of yeast. The barrel ageing i found came out more in the flavor and the finish, touches of wood, and a little oak. It seemed to dim the funkiness a bit, but it added so e much welcome complexity. The funk was present all the way through with some light pepperiness. Quite a solid saison, great stuff!

A: The pour is a somewhat minimally hazed golden-orange color with a large white head.

S: There is a mild tartness on the nose, which I find pleasant.  Definitely some apples along with a pronounced honeydew melon aroma and a bit of celery.   Earth and spice notes as well as some wood and cracker malts.

T: The flavor has a mild sweet of bread and cracker malts.  There is definitely some grass, celery, and earthy mushroom.  A fair amount of fruits, especially green melon, lemon zest, and apples.

M: Medium in body with a medium to high carbonation.

O: Lots of complexity to this one and I thought it was pretty nice to drink.

Bottle. Pours a hazy pale gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges and laces nicely. Aroma has some earthy grains with a bit of fruit and a backing dry red wine note. Flavor starts with earthy grains and grows with some fruits and a dry red wine finish that had a bit of an oak note.

Thank you, yespr. Mild citric note, like barrelled brett, perhaps white wine. Hazy dark yellow colour. The flavour is a lot like the aroma, citric, grape peel, very refreshing. Earthy notes, like from good old Belgian barrels. Great.

Tasted on 5/30/11 from a 750mL bottle, thanks to Ryan.  Pours cloudy yellow-orange with a thick, rocky white head, which slowly recedes to a decently sized smooth layer of lace.  The nose is earthy and funky with some spicy yeast, a hint of yeast, and a bit of candi sugar sweetness.  The flavor is earthy and funky with bitter lemon peel, vanilla oak, and a pleasant dose of spicy yeast.  The body is medium with lively carbonation, and a long bitter lemon peel, earthy finish with some light vanilla oak.

Golden orange color, got whiff of light funk as my glass passed my nose. Aroma has mor spice on top of that, some sweetness and citrus. Almost a touch of rye, or pepper. Dried out nicely, finishes clean with spice and sweetness and a touch of dry brett, but not overly funky.

Bottle 750ml. @ yespr blindtasting. [ Bottle #2. ]Clear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy yeasty, fruity, brett, wood - wine ? Flavour to heavy is moderate sweet and bitter with a long duration, sharp, damp stain - fusty, stabel, mold, late late finish wood - earthy - fusty. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20110526]

Pours a pale hazy golden yellow/straw color with golden banana yellow hues and a frothy two finger white head.  Good retention slowly fading into a lasting cap that leaves streaks of soapy lacing.  

Sweet yet earthy aroma with subtle barnyard funk, sweet honey, light fruit, banana, citrus, bready yeast and zesty spice.  Subtle toasted oak but not much of a barrel presence.

Fuller bodied than expected with tight carbonation up front Lots of zesty spice with hints of pepper, lemon peel and coriander.  Earthy funk countered by sweet fruit and bready yeast.  Good balance of funk, sweetness and dryness.  Spicy with bready yeast, light fruit and citrus.  Funkier as it warms but not sour.  More dry/bretty than anything with a faint barrel presence.   Some earthy wood but it is subtle not overpowering the other flavors.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2013 Hill farmstead art. 750ml bottle shared with everyone at olbutikken...  
Pours a golden and vivid apricot orangey vividness and topped with a  
frothy white head... An herbal grassy nose with a saison yeasty  
fruitiness, a little bit dusty. A little medicinal, some asprin...  
Flavors are much of the same with an earthy bitterness and light  
asparin, saison yeast profile, light pale grapefruit. Little wild with  
active carbonation and a light to medium body.
8/4/7/4/14

Tasted again on 6/2... Better more tart with a nice white wine aspect. A bit of metallic comes into play a bit but goes in and out. A lot nicer than originally tasted. This was a batch 2 bottle. Rating updated to reflect batch 2 over the first.

Draft, RBSG bus trip.  Medium off-white head, hazy light amber body.  Aroma is medium sweet, spicy, some orange.  Taste is medium sweet, spicy, some orange, light funk, fairly dry finish.  Light-medium body, soft, light acidity.
on tap @Capones RBSG-pours a white head with trailing lace and yellow/gold color.  Aroma is tart, light/medium malt.  Taste is tart-lemon, spice hops, light/medium malt.

Tap at Capones. Transparent gold, thin white ring light lace. Lightly metallic. Rindy nose, bit of yeast. Flavor carries light bit across, light yeast and pepper, honey. There was an off-vanilla note in my glass not found in anothers.

Yellowish golden colour, small white head. Aroma is sour wood, farmyard, some mild apples as well. Flavour is rather barnyardy, some mild fruityness as well as some earthyness. Really pleasant Saison.

Thanks to largadeer.  Hazy golden in color with a small but lasting white head and great lacing.  Aroma is excellent, bretty and citrusy with white wine and lots of yeast.  Dry and yeasty flavor with pineapple and a good oakiness.  Medium-bodied, dry and only mildly tannic. Overall this is impressive.  Im a big fan.
Bottle at Capones at RBSG. Pours cloudy gold. White head. Nose/taste of oak, lemon zest, yeast, honey comb, grassy hops and pineapple. Medium body. Slight spiciness.

Tap at Capones for RBSG Philly 2011/Philly Beer Week. The pour is a clear bright golden with a healthy white head. Giant, webby lace all over the snifter. White lace explosion. The nose on this took me awhile to decipher, but whatever funky house yeast Shaun is using comes across as straight Brie cheese and Brie cheese rind. Very mildly creamy, briny, and sharp. Im digging this nose a lot those it comes across a little bit papery. As it opens up it becomes floral and Bretty. Taste feels more integrated than Flora with more depth. More Bretty and fruity with sweet grapefruit, sweet oranges, mild celery (found in many saisons) juxtaposed with salty caramel and Brie cheese. As it opens up one could argue it gets a little bit geuzy and funky. Very interesting and loveable.
(Draught)  Pours a clear yellow body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of lemon, leather, pineapple, light barnyard, and oak.  Flavor of citrus, vanilla, yeast, nuts, and oak.
Tap at Hawthornes in Philly.  Frothy and straw colored.  Mellowed down from barrel aging.. had side by side with citra so I couldnt give this much love.

On tap at Capones.  Foggy pale orange with a white head.  Nose is orange peel, candied ginger, nutmeg and grass.  Medium light with a mild sparkle.  Taste is lemon custard, herbs and citrus peel.  An interesting blend with a spicy finish.

Funked out bretty pineapple and horseblanket nose thats just a bit goaty with flowers and honey. The taste is lightly sweet and just a touch tart, with pineapple, juicy peach, peppery yeast, floral hops and clover honey.

Bottle 75 cl. Blindtasting. Courtesy of yespr. Pours an opaque golden with a tiny white head. The nose is citrusy with a tart barnyard edge. Medium body, very dry fruitiness, a little yeast and again lots of barnyard. Very dry and bitter finish. 260511

On Tap at Hill Farmstead 1st Ann. 
Hazy Golden pour with a fluffy white head.  These HF saisons are such beautiful beers to behold.  Aroma is yeast, pineapple sweet fruitiness, wetwood, light cheesy twang.  Flavor is more pineapple creaminess, zesty floral notes, honeysuckle, barnyard funk, with a dry bretty finish.  Supremely smooth, rich and complex while still retaining most of the refreshing drinkability that was Arthur.

75 cL bottle. Pours almost clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is citrusy, funk and slight barnyard. Crisp bitter, funky, barnyard and slight citrusy hoppy. Bitter and crisp barnyard hoppy finish.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2012 On tap at Hill Farmsteads first anniversary celebration. A hazy golden straw body sits under a magnanimous white froth. The nose holds awesome lemon acidity, fruity dough, and cheesy brett tartness. The flavor holds woody yeast, citrus acidity, and more delicious brett inoculation. The palate leads to dangerous drinkability- I found myself on my 4th consecutive glass rather quickly...

Bottle at Yespr - Blind Tasting #2. Clear yellow/golden - white head. Apple freshness, fruity, light bubblegum, peppery, ko stald, bretty, light flowery, light wooden/barrel, light tannins, smooth, bitterness, zesty. grape fruits. Nice.
#2 at yespr beertasting  Cloudy yellow, small white head. aroma is sourish, mild, dry, bretty?, flavor is grassy, sour, dry, wood. Very dry flavor.

On tap at Hill Farmsteads 1st Anniversary. Cloudy golden pour with a big white head. Aroma and flavor are marked by a beautiful dry tartness, awesome tropical fruit presence, and the phenomenal bready and lemony presence of a typical saison. The barrel/Brett treatment really did wonderful things for this beer. Lovely stuff.

Bottled. Blind no 2 @ Yesprs. Golden coloured. Full of floaties. Off white small head. Aroma of sweetness, yeast, fruits, barnyard. Flavour of yeast, sourness, grape, barrel, spice, Medium to full bodied. Has a yeasty and sourish end. Very refreshing.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy golden yellow orange with a thick and creamy off white head.  Aroma of zesty lemon, Chardonnay notes, oak wood and pineapple.  Taste of Chardonnay notes, oak wood, zesty lemon, light peppery hints and yeast.  Very nice and refreshing.
A hazy dark golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of malt, lemon, spices, and pepper. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, spices, yeast, and fruit, leading to a bitter finish.

750ml bottle sent to me by deyholla--thanks Derek! Great looking bottle and appearance of beer after pouring. Color was a very light, golden yellow and very clean looking. About a three finger head that was super frothy and a light cloudy white. I got vinous notes on the nose along with a bit of spice and wood. Described by Shane as "smelling like a cave." Taste is grape-smashed hard wood and ends somewhat bitter with notes of grapefruit rind and bitter grape skin. A very different beer thats very much worth a sampling!

Bottle at yesprs blindtasting.
Clear yellow coloured with a medium sized white head.
Fruity aroma of hops, grass and brett with notes of grapes.
Fruity flavour of brett, hops and barnyard with murky notes.
Dry hoppy finish.
Hazed yellow pour with white head and lace. Aroma of straw and wheat. Wheaty brett flavor. Thin and a bit fizzy. drinkable

Thanks to Sam for sharing.  Bright hazy orange pour with a fluffy white head.  Aroma shows light funk, earthy notes and citrus.  Maybe even some subtle hints of tropical fruit and oak.  Dusty funkiness with lingering notes of Citrus, white peppercorn,and a pleasant wine like barrel note.  Dry finish.  Kinda a weird phenolic/ bubblegum aftertaste (guess its a saison so its not that weird).  Phenolics, the one thing I dislike in many classic beer styles thankfully this is far from an intense phenolic experience but, its still there. On a side note: Imagine a truly infected version of this stuff.

Bottle.  Thanks Shaun.  Another fantastic saison.  Definitely one of the dryest saisons I have ever had.  Dryer than Dupont.   Citrus, zest, light pineapple, some oaky white wine character, light spice.

Thanks turdferguson for sharing. Pours cloudy straw yellow with two fingers of frothy white head. Zesty/citrusy nose with notes of pineapple and white pepper, a mild vinous character with some tannic oak. Brett? Vinous and dry palate. Some phenolic character. Very very dry. Flavor is not as delicate, peppery and spicy with notes of hibiscus.

Thanks to Chris for this... A hazy dark honey gold with a big white head, fluffy with a good lace... Aroma is outstanding, sweet overall, light sweet grape juice, grape skin, sweet oak, a bit of musky oak, not saisonish... Taste is good but as great as I was hoping, a lot of the sweetness of the nose is gone, musky oak, very oaky overall, a bit bitter... Nice mouthfeel... Really good and worth trying but a slight let down after an outstanding start

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2017 Pours  gold - a slight bit of haze with a puffy 3 finger head that leaves big rings of lace.  Aromas of earthy brett, lemon, white grape, hay and oak - very complex.  Taste is spot on - light Oaked malts balanced with a hint of dry white grape, green apple, lemongrass, white pepper and very slight bitterness and sourness - VERY easy to drink.  Medium bodied with fairly high carbonation.  A winner and worth the long drive to the farmstead!

Huge, huge thanks to sisuspeed for opening this bottle at the Rosso release. Served in a SAVOR snifter.

Pours a mild straw color with a really nice, fluffy white head that sticks around for quite a bit of time. Really nice lacing as it goes down. The nose is really nice with some complex earthy funk as well as grain and hay plus a touch of oak. Funk keeps coming, and also brings a hint of white grapes and mild stone fruit. The flavor is along the same lends, blending the funk with the base malt well and adding in slight fruit complexity. Mildly sweet feel is fairly light with a nicely dry finish. Really fantastic. Thanks again, John.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-20-2011

Draft @ Blind Tiger. Golden pour with white head. Golden pour with white head. Brett, oak, citrus, funk, and earthy aroma notes. Flavors include dry fruit, musky tones, earthy bitterness, and funky tones.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2016 Sampled at Blind Tiger in NYC on draft with Pat. Pours a hazy orange body with nice foamy head/lacing. Aroma is fruity tart notes. Mouthfeel is smooth and light with notes of tart, lemon, orange, funk.Rerated 2016: 750mL bottle courtesy of Kevin, shared with Alan and Paul & Kevin (huge thanks for this one!) Notes consistent of tart oak, delicate, pillowy & juicy palate with sour fruit, sour grape skins, tropical gummy bears and tart fruit. Great stuff. +0.1
Draft. Pours golden orange with a white head. Funky oaky aroma, with yeasty, spicy, and light fruity notes. The flavor is oaky and funky, with saison spicy yeast, fruity and flowery notes. Nice.

On draft at Blind Tiger for the Hill Farmstead event with James. Pours a blisteringly bright, yet hazy, neon yellowish orange with a tall, two-finger, bubbly white sudsy white head. Aroma is marked by tons of sharp, savory farmhouse funkiness, along with some zesty orange, lemon, and peach tang, some soft pineapple and guava notes, and a lovely wash of soft oaky, vanilla, earthy notes. Sipping this beer, the first tastes to roll over the tongue are lemon, honey, and tons of tart, lactic acidic notes. Hugely juicy, yet stunningly dry and tongue sappingly dry. Very, very special beer.

Poured into a Hill Farmstead tasting glass. A clear, straw-yellow body holds up a thick, foamy, white head. Each sip leaves some beautiful lacing on the glass.

Wet hay and earthy oak rise up from a few swirls of the glass. Light fruits and a touch of yeast spice on the nose. Faint white wine grapes and a light brett presence add to the complexity.

Dry, oaky, earthy malts mixed with light wine barrel fruitiness compose the taste. Faint orchard fruit, apple, hay and earthiness. Malts, yeast and barrels in perfect harmony. Exceptional.

Mouthfeel is earthy and musty with a touch of sweetness, but mostly dry throughout. Feels great for the style.

Overall, this is an amazing saison. Essentially flawless in every way. From the nose, to the flavor, to the mouthfeel, Shaun has nailed this one on the head. The wine oak barrels plus the house yeast make this a truly unique and exceptional saison. Probably in my top 3 for the style, if not my favorite. Highly recommended.

Vintage 2011. 

A soft pour into a tilted tulip immediately spurs a huge pillowy white head of four fingers. The head leaves massive, thick and large-bubbled lacing, softly settling into a finger and a half. The beer itself has mezmerizing clarity (like Anna) on first pour - the tangerine body is clear and luminous. 

A nice bouquet of citrus, oak, and some mineral character. Theres some wet hay and pineapple from the brett. The citrus runs deeply through it, with just a hint of sourness. (This reminds me a lot of good bottles of Sanctification, with the addition of oak.)

The oakiness gives way to citrus thats more orange than lemon in expression. Theres a little bit of white pepper here, along with a constant mustiness and earthiness that envelops the citrus on the front of the palate and the minerality on the finish. A light sourness cuts through the must. The lingering bitterness on the finish whets my palate before the next sip. The tiniest bit of sulphur / rubber in the mid- and late-palate keeps this from a perfect score. 

Medium-light in body with high carbonation (though the body feels slick and oily on the front of the tongue). Medium dryness on the finish.

This saison is drinking elegantly right off the bat, and Im glad I opened this one early, since it displays such a restrained balance (though I would like to dry it after the brett has worked itself more overtly into the beer). A very well imagined saison and likely my favorite to date. I need more of this.

Bottle shared during AZRBWG.  Pour is hazy gold with a white head.  Aroma shows notes of lemon peel, toast, white pepper, and light funk.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of pineapple, pear, and vanilla.  Overall body is light to moderate, dry, tart and somewhat bitter.

Bottle at RBWG 2011 Grand Tasting. Pours cloudy gold, 1-finger white head, spotty/soft lacing. nose is spicy, sherbet lemons, white pepper, earth, sour cream/yogurt. Flavours of earth, sour lemons, dry earthy peppercorns, sour cream. Lovely, not the equal of Anna, but lovely.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2011 Hazy golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of brett, vanilla, toast, citrus, and spices.  Taste of brett, citrus, light honey, faint spices, vanilla, and finishing dry, with a bit of tartness.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a medium creamy white head.  Aroma of lemons, floral, herbal notes, bread and Brett.  Flavor of lemon juice, earthy, spicy saison character, some vanilla and rather intense bitterness.

Draft.  Pours a hazy golden body with a light off white head.  Aromatically brett y and wild dry and musky with some earth tones and lighter lemon pear notes.  Nice dry bittering earth and funky fruit tones.   Very dry finish with no warming.  Delicious and dam drinkable brew.

Tap at Blind Tiger. Pours extremely hazy, gold, with medium white head. Really nice bretty aroma with notes of of sour cherry, oak, pine, and soap. The flavor is more hop-heavy with notes of lemon and oak. Slight smokiness and earthiness with a bit too much hop sting in the finish. Good beer that could be even better if that brett and cherry aroma came out more in the flavor.

On tap at the Blind Tiger.  Pours a hazed orange gold with a medium to large white head.  Soft and fazzy, light funk and some subtle sour notes.  Smooth, with some nice yeast and light brett.  Nice and earthy, with some citrus and musk, more gentle brett.  Slow musky finish.  Would love to see a fully soured up version of this.
Tap at Blind Tiger -  fruity tart with spicy funk. Hazy orange pour. Very aroumatic, bretty. Dry finish, and soft bodied. Very tasty.

Tap at BT.  Pours a hazed golden dull yellow with a nice tight sulky off white head.  Aroma is clean fruitines, mineral, white wine- chardonnay/txakoli mix- vibrant minerally stone fruits, peach and pear, then some wild funk like fruity pineapple, light farmhouse without getting horsey- slight woodiness as well.  Flavor is light toast, light grass and bready malts, cracker, more pineapple, wood, lemon zest, some slight red apple cider- moslty skins, tannic, but no acetaldehyde, finish is light funk and wood with a soft ending- and very dry.  Really nice.

On tap at Hill Farmstead Winter Gathering 2010..
Appearance : Hazy pale yellow.

Aroma : Nice brett with light citrusy notes. Nice funk and horse blanket notes.

Taste : Malt and brett with hops. A bit herbal and yeasty too. Nice fruits. Dry fiish.

Overall : Utterly drinkable, very tasty. Nice funk, nice balance. Cant wait to try a bottle of this and complete my rating.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2011 My Bottom Line:
This Wild Saison dazzles the senses with white wine complexity, matching citrusy, herbal hop notes to levelled brettanomyces in a dry and highly drinkable vehicle. What an appropriately named beer.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A creamy tower of foam decorates the shiny yellow.
-The citrusy character is also redolent of citrusy thyme and citrus peel.
-Carbonation is adorably fluffy.
-The oak character blends into the well-developed flavor spectrum. Works perfectly with the wild yeast and fruity hop spiciness.
-The herbal hop bitterness is balanced with the rest of the brews medium intensity.
-The white wine is more apparent in the first half of the bottle if you dont pour any yeast in your glass.

On tap at Hill Farmstead and from a few bottles.
